title: Sleep and cortisol levels
content: Matthew discusses the effect of cortisol levels on sleep and the efficacy and risks associated with the most common sleeping pills.

title: Sleep and cardiovascular disease
content: Short sleep duration and incident coronary artery calcification. Study tracked healthy adults without signs of CVD. By the end of the study, those getting 5 hrs of sleep or less had a 200-300% increased risk of coronary artery calcification. The study controlled for factors like exercise, smoking, BMI, snoring, etc. Lack of sleep increases blood pressure (hypertension). Having an ApoE4 gene is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s, but one study showed that if you are normotensive (normal blood pressure), you don’t necessarily have an increased risk of Alzheimer’s disease, but if you are hypertensive, then your Alzheimer’s disease risk is far higher.

title: Fuel partitioning and dieting while sleep deprived
content: Dietary changes when you are sleep deprived: Inferior fuel partitioning. Hyperinsulinemia. Impaired glucose disposal. A tendency to probably eat more crap. The energy balance of organism (regulation and input) – how much to eat and how the body uses it – is affected by sleep. RQ (respiratory quotient) goes up when sleep deprived. Respiratory quotient going up implies that under the same level of exertion, you would preferentially go after glycogen for ATP, as opposed to fat. This signals a metabolic inefficiency. This great study showed that dieting when underslept (6 hrs or less) was much less effective in terms of fat loss. If underslept, 70% of what you lose is from lean muscle mass (the body holds onto fat). A big reason for this above is the high levels of cortisol (stress hormone) and insulin.

title: Sleep and the reproductive function: testosterone, sperm count, FSH, menstrual cycles, and fertility
content: Testosterone in men. Men who only get 5-6 hrs sleep have testosterone levels of men 10 years older. Men who sleep 5 hrs a night have smaller testicles. Men who sleep 6 hrs or less have fewer sperm and their sperm have more deformities in the sperm. FSH and LH in women. Women who sleep 5-6 hrs have a 20% reduction in FSH (a critical part of the reproductive pathway). They also have a 30% higher rate of abnormal menstrual cycles.

title: Fasting and Reproduction
content: Men don’t seem to be less able to reproduce in a fasted state. But women do tend to be less capable of reproducing when in a fasted state (study, in rats). This could be due to the rise in FGF21, and the inhibition of FSH in women. Seems that the keto diet could also have negative side effect on women trying to reproduce by increasing FGF21. Would not recommended fasting or keto diet if a woman is trying to conceive.

title: Sleep Deprivation
content: Human beings are the only species that deliberately deprive themselves of sleep for no apparent reason. You almost never see other organisms undergo sleep deprivation. Presumably because evolutionarily speaking they need to be more alert to search for food. But be cautious because this feeling is temporary and you’re still accumulating sleep debt. Mother Nature has never had to face challenge of sleep deprivation, so no biological “safety nets” for any essential functions without sleep. People think they can accumulate sleep debt during week and then make it up on weekend (“social jet lag”). It’s like sleep bulimia (with binging and purging). It’s torture on circadian biology to drag body clock by 3 hours every weekend (“It’s like flying from San Francisco to New York every weekend.”).

title: Tools to Course Correct Sleep Problems
content: There is a whole arsenal of tools in the sleep doc kind of box that we can use, to sort of make these manipulations, either be it for people with insomnia, be it people with anxiety, be it people with jet lag, or what’s called circadian phase delay. Exogenous agents like melatonin, blue light, regular exercise, exposure to daylight, even manipulations of body temperature. About 2 hours before wake up, see drop in temperature. In Peter’s patient’s case, his temp was dropping at 1am so they needed to move the temperature drop 4am.

title: Sleep and Cancer
content: Significant link between sleep and cancer of bowel, prostate, and breast (3 of top 4 cancers). Causal evidence so strong that WHO has classified night shift work as a “probable carcinogen”. For the development of cancer, a couple things must go wrong: First, a genetic insult. Second, that insult must be missed by immune system (most of the time T cells identify it).

title: Partial sleep deprivation reduces natural killer cell activity in humans
content: A UCLA study found that healthy adults limited to 4 hours of sleep for one night experienced a 70% drop in natural killer cell activity. This is significant because natural killer cells identify foreign elements like cancer cells and destroy them. Peter Attia notes that our immune system is always protecting us from cancer, and that the weakening of the adaptive immune system is almost assuredly playing a role in why we get cancer more as we age.

title: Sleep and cancer development
content: A study using mice by David Gozal at the University of Chicago found that underslept mice had tumors 200% larger than mice who slept normally. The cancer in underslept mice had also metastasized. The mechanism behind this is that macrophage M1 cells are downregulated, and M2 cells (which promote tumor growth) are upregulated by lack of sleep. In humans, both the M2 cells upregulated as well as a “tsunami” of cortisol impacting the body and driving tumor growth.

title: The medical profession: A culture that devalues sleep
content: Despite the fact that sleep takes up 1/3 of your life and makes such a huge difference to the 2/3 of life spent awake, most medical students get 1-2 hours of instruction about sleep during medical school. Medicine is a culture that devalues sleep, which is a stark example in medical school.

title: Sleep Prescription for Medicine
content: Matthew’s article in The Lancet highlights the importance of sleep for both patients and doctors. Lack of sleep can lead to major surgical errors, car crashes, and medical errors. One in five residents make errors due to insufficient sleep, and one in 20 will kill a patient. ER docs who work a 30-hour shift make 460% more diagnostic errors. Despite the evidence, medical organizations resist change.

title: Peter’s Residency Story
content: Peter’s residency stories highlight the extreme sleep deprivation that doctors face. He averaged 2-2.5 hours of sleep every 3rd night that he was on call. Lack of sleep can lead to dangerous situations, such as falling asleep during surgery or making medical errors. Matthew argues that the medical field needs to prioritize sleep to protect both patients and doctors.

title: Continuity of Care
content: The only argument against shift limits is continuity of care, but Matthew uses examples from New Zealand, Sweden, and France to show that limiting doctors to 12-16 hour shifts can still result in highly ranked medical systems. The 80-hour work week did not solve the problem in the US, possibly due to a different mentality towards handing off patients. Peter believes that continuity of care is a difficult problem, but it is too important not to change.

title: Sleep Needs of Children
content: Matthew argues that school start times are impacting the sleep of children. Delaying school start times can lead to improved grades, attendance, and behavior, as well as a reduction in car crashes. Peter agrees that school start times should be changed, despite the difficulties in implementation.

title: The sleep needs and sleep habits of teens
content: Teens need to go to bed later and sleep later. They need 9-10 hrs sleep even when 16-18 years old, but only ~11% kids get that much sleep. On average, teens get about 7 hrs of sleep which is a bigger relative deficit than in adults. Parental disconnect: 72% of parents think their teen is getting enough sleep. The need to sleep to later time is not always solved by earlier bedtime.

title: The impact of a later start time
content: When you delay school start times, SAT scores improve, and grades in morning classes specifically improve greatly. A 10am start time “is probably sweet spot”. UK has proposed a bill for 10am start times. Much of criminal behavior happens between 3-4pm when kids are out of school and parents aren’t yet home from work. So cost of starting school later and getting out later limits criminal opportunity window and pays for itself.

title: What else can parents do (if later start time isn’t an option)?
content: Try to excise technology and turn off lights. On the basic impact of light, we are “dark deprived” and we need darkness to release melatonin. This study suggests using an iPad before bed has negative effect on sleep ⇒ 50% drop in melatonin (aka you lose 50% signal of sleep timing), and your peak melatonin will arrive 3. iPad time also reduces REM time. Effects last 2-3 days. Television ⇒ TV doesn’t have quite the same effect, but… it does make brain associate bedroom with TV and “when you start to form those maladaptive associations, it can be a trigger of insomnia and anxiety.

title: The mental component
content: Devices can cause sleep procrastination (Since it’s there, I’ll check email or FB one more time). Surveys suggest many kids wake up during night to check phones to check phones or social media. Devices and technologies cause what’s called anticipatory anxiety. Most people, the first thing that they do when they wake up in the morning unlock this world of anxiety that comes flooding in through their phone (Emails, texts, social media, etc.). You essentially are training your brain to anticipate that wave of anxiety every morning. That anticipatory expectation in the morning lessens the amount of deep sleep that you get. You end up sleeping in a shallow state, and you don’t get the same amount of deep sleep.

title: Recommendations for kids getting more and better sleep
content: Limit tech for kids is best thing to do now to maximize sleep if school starts early. Get tech out of bedroom. Social media in bedroom also leads to FOMO (fear of missing out), which leads to insufficient sleep at night. Teenage sleep problem has no easy solution, but we need to stop fighting biology.

title: How exposure to light affects sleep, and how modern society has changed our sleep habits
content: LED bulbs are more deleterious in terms of suppressing melatonin. Warm red and yellow light is best, though all light will interfere with melatonin. Lower wattage light is best for reading at night. We’ve reduced the amount of sleep. We’ve changed the timing of sleep. So we’re getting less sleep and perhaps at the “wrong” time. And finally the nature in which we obtain our sleep has been changed. It seems as though we are designed perhaps to be sleeping biphasically, which is a long bout at night, and then a siesta like nap in the afternoon.

title: Looking at hunter gatherers
content: Many sleep “biphasically” which means (long night sleep and then nap in afternoon). Hunter-gatherer tribes go to bed at 8:30- 9 pm. Get 7-7.5 hrs of sleep. Then nap in afternoon to make it about 9 hours total. Examples include: Gabra in northern Kenya, San people in the Kalahari Desert.

title: Another model of sleep
content: Sleep 4 hours, wake then go back for another 4 hours. Called the “Two sleeps” or the “First sleep and second sleep”. That has happened around “Dickensian” era (1800s), but seems to have been a feature of social pressure (often ate in between). This is not the way we’re designed to sleep. And there’s a great book written on this, says Matthew.

title: Is napping helpful?
content: Experiments show naps benefit learning, memory, immune function, & CV health and lower systolic BP. 20 minute naps: “What we’ve found is that you can go down as low as about 20 minutes of a nap, and still see some mental benefits, in terms of things like learning and memory.” In Why We Sleep, Matthew adds “so long as they contain enough non-REM sleep”. 90 minutes naps: “That gives the ability of the brain to go through the full 90 minutes cycle, so that the brain can go through all of the stages of non-REM sleep, stages one through four, and it gets the shot to get to REM sleep.” In studies, nappers showed improvements in multiple parameters compared to controls who were relaxing in bed but not asleep.

title: Adenosine and Sleep
content: The more builds up, the sleepier you feel. After 16 hrs you should have enough to fall and stay asleep. During sleep, the brain will clear adenosine away, remove 16 hours of accumulated adenosine. If you nap during day, especially in late afternoon, harder to fall asleep because nap removed some of the adenosine. That said… if you can nap regularly and are still able to fall asleep at night, naps are fine.

title: Cortisol and Sleep
content: Sleep is balance among adenosine, cortisol, and melatonin (like an orchestra). Crescendo of adenosine. Then decrescendo of cortisol. Then melatonin comes in. Peter suspects that any sleeping issues he has are due to the cortisol axis. His reasoning for thinking this is that he measures his melatonin levels and sees no problem there. But since he measures his glucose levels continuously (with CGM), and he considers glucose levels a proxy for cortisol levels, he has noticed that “the association between high night time glucose, and poor sleep, is overwhelming. And I suspect that it’s through this cortisol axis.”

title: Insomnia and Cortisol
content: Matthew says that the leading theory of insomnia is that the flight or flight/parasympathetic state of the nervous system is “turned up” too far. In cases of insomnia: Cortisol is down in evening but then right before bed it spikes again (sleep onset insomnia), sometimes spikes again in middle of night and keeping someone from falling back asleep (sleep maintenance insomnia). Walker guesses that if you measured HR variability, looking at contribution of sympathetic vs. parasympathetic systems, you would see sympathetic getting revved up just before sleep onset and then again in middle of night, underlying cortisol spike, which underlies awakening, which underlies insomnia.

title: Treating High Nighttime Cortisol
content: Peter says that clinically this very hard to treat. Much easier to treat thyroid or sex hormone dysfunction. Also, easier to treat low sympathetic and low glucocorticoid function rather than the reverse. Hardest problem is high sympathetic and high glucocorticoid output. Behavioral therapy is required: i.e. changes in mindset (meditation) and routine (less stressful activities close to bedtime such as work emails). Phosphatidylserine (400-600 mg): Peter uses this for jet lag circumstances (e.g., must go to bed when it’s only 2 pm in your brain) ⇒ “Phosphatidylserine really seems to move the needle, both in terms of your glucose response and your cortisol response.”

title: Meditation and Sleep
content: In researching the data on meditation and sleep, Matthew says… “The data was very compelling”. Decreases the amount of time it takes someone to fall asleep. Improves the continuity of their sleep. Meditation apps (like Headspace or Calm) … if you were to look at their usage statistics, you will already see that people are self medicating their insomnia by way of meditating right before bed.

title: Metformin vs. Diet
content: Peter believes that Metformin is a powerful pill, but not nearly as powerful as an exceptional diet. He thinks that molecules that you take intermittently aren’t really nearly as potent as molecular changes that occur over a time course, behaviorally.

title: Sleeping Pills
content: Peter says that sleeping pills on the market now don’t produce naturalistic sleep, have a higher risk of death, and a higher risk of cancer. He also shares his experience with Ambien, which he used to take to sleep on cross-country flights. He had several scary lapses of memory and Ambien isn’t like sleep, it’s more like a “chemical baseball bat to the head” than something that’s actually promoting restorative and restful sleep.

title: Sedative-hypnotics
content: Current sleep drugs like Ambien and Lunesta are sedative-hypnotics. Sedation is not sleep, it’s knocking your cortex out. It’s not the same quality of deep sleep and has a higher association with mortality risk and linked to cancer.

title: The Effects of Sleeping Pills on Brain Plasticity
content: Peter shares a study by Marcos Frank that shows how sleep strengthens the brain’s plasticity, which leads to the formation of memories. However, when animals were dosed with Ambien, it led to 50% unwiring of connections that had been laid down before. Peter expresses concern about parents giving sleeping pills to their children, as it may actually be un-wiring their nervous system and memories, rather than strengthening them.
